body: @mistercrunch gotcha, i will fix this.
@Gowtham95india I've run into this same exact issue, can you share details about how this was resolved? Documentation in a comment is better than none at all.
`1.7.0` is out so this would be `1.7.1rc1` or `1.7.0.1`

Here's where it would go in the docs:
https://github.com/airbnb/superset/blob/master/docs/installation.rst
Note that you should run  `superset worker`

I just found about `superset worker` after my read through the config file. I managed to get it running with redis, but haven't figured out how to do so with sqlite (due to sqla not being a supported transport?). I'll probably add in a small section for setting up celery now that I've been through it,
ah! got it, thx.

sqla is experimental, I think it should work on small workloads like Superset would typically generate, but I'd use a proper threaded DB, not sqllite for celery on sqla.

Either see how much mileage you can get on that or setup Redis which is pretty easy and has been zero-maintenance in our case.
LGTM thanks! I'll add an entry in the runbook
it does for me, not sure what I'm missing...
Should be fixed in 0.17.0, reopen if you see it there

@balchandra it would involve using this:
https://github.com/loverajoel/sqlalchemy-elasticquery
I usually do it but skipped it on a few releases. Its up to date now

@aurora5161 Not yet. We decide use the `superset` that version is `0.15.4` in product environment. Newest version `0.16.0` `superset`'s test coverage is too low to use it as formal product. I think if you are not very anxious, you can wait a while for a more stable version of the release. :-)

superset db upgrade

You uploaded some logs logs not a backtrace of the exceptions that caused the error. You have to first reproduce the error and then copy the backtrace from the logs here.

Here is the full backtrace with pandas==0.19.2:
```
[2017-03-07 12:45:21,790: INFO/MainProcess] Received task: superset.sql_lab.get_sql_results[881d070f-f286-4f8d-b25f-ce6f450a8df1]
[2017-03-07 12:45:21,879: INFO/Worker-23] Running query:
select '2017-01-02'::timestamp - '2017--01-01'::timestamp as t_diff
[2017-03-07 12:45:21,911: ERROR/MainProcess] Task superset.sql_lab.get_sql_results[881d070f-f286-4f8d-b25f-ce6f450a8df1] raised unexpected: TypeError("Unserializable object 1 days 00:00:00 of type <class 'pandas.tslib.Timedelta'>",)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/apps/superset/venv_py3_superset/lib/python3.4/site-packages/celery/app/trace.py", line 240, in trace_task
    R = retval = fun(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/opt/apps/superset/venv_py3_superset/lib/python3.4/site-packages/celery/app/trace.py", line 438, in __protected_call__
    return self.run(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/opt/apps/superset/venv_py3_superset/lib/python3.4/site-packages/superset/sql_lab.py", line 152, in get_sql_results
    payload = json.dumps(payload, default=utils.json_iso_dttm_ser)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/json/__init__.py", line 237, in dumps
    **kw).encode(obj)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/json/encoder.py", line 192, in encode
    chunks = self.iterencode(o, _one_shot=True)
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/json/encoder.py", line 250, in iterencode
    return _iterencode(o, 0)
  File "/opt/apps/superset/venv_py3_superset/lib/python3.4/site-packages/superset/utils.py", line 275, in json_iso_dttm_ser
    "Unserializable object {} of type {}".format(obj, type(obj))
TypeError: Unserializable object 1 days 00:00:00 of type <class 'pandas.tslib.Timedelta'>
```

I'm trying to debug it. It seems that the field 'country_fieldtype' is None in the server, but it has a value in the frontend. Even that fields appears correctly in the URI:

/superset/explore/table/2/?form_data=%7B%22datasource%22%3A%20%222__table%22%2C%20%22compare_suffix%22%3A%20%22o10Y%22%2C%20%22secondary_metric%22%3A%20%22sum__SP_POP_TOTL%22%2C%20%22granularity%22%3A%20%22year%22%2C%20%22slice_id%22%3A%208%2C%20%22row_limit%22%3A%2050000%2C%20%22entity%22%3A%20%22country_code%22%2C%20%22since%22%3A%20%222014-01-01%22%2C%20%22num_period_compare%22%3A%20%2210%22%2C%20%22groupby%22%3A%20%5B%5D%2C%20%22viz_type%22%3A%20%22world_map%22%2C%20%22until%22%3A%20%222014-01-02%22%2C%20%22markup_type%22%3A%20%22markdown%22%2C%20%22where%22%3A%20%22%22%2C%20%22metric%22%3A%20%22sum__SP_RUR_TOTL_ZS%22%2C%20%22**country_fieldtype%22%3A%20%22cca3%22%2C%20%22**show_bubbles%22%3A%20true%2C%20%22metrics%22%3A%20%5B%22sum__SP_POP_TOTL%22%5D%2C%20%22compare_lag%22%3A%20%2210%22%2C%20%22limit%22%3A%20%2225%22%7D

Does it make sense? Have I missing any package that I should install or configure anything?

I see lots of discussion on Explore V2, but I've just upgraded to Superset 0.17.0, expecting shiny shiny things, but nothings changed. 

Is there yet a way to use Explore V2 on the PyPI release, or will I have to clone and build from source.

I keep debugging it. It seems that the constructor of the `WorldMapViz` is called twice. The first time the `form_data` is this:

`{'metrics': ['sum__SP_POP_TOTL'], 'granularity': 'year', 'metric': 'sum__SP_RUR_TOTL_ZS', 'compare_suffix': 'o10Y', 'secondary_metric': 'sum__SP_POP_TOTL', 'until': '2014-01-02', 'entity': 'country_code', 'row_limit': 50000, 'num_period_compare': '10', 'country_fieldtype': 'cca3', 'where': '', 'since': '2014-01-01', 'compare_lag': '10', 'markup_type': 'markdown', 'show_bubbles': True, 'limit': '25', 'viz_type': 'world_map', 'groupby': []}`

Which has the correct param: ` 'country_fieldtype': 'cca3'`

The second time the constructor is called, the param is missing:

`{'slice_id': 8, 'granularity_sqla': 'year', 'since': '2014-01-01', 'until': '2014-01-02', 'where': '', 'entity': 'country_code', 'metric': 'sum__SP_RUR_TOTL_ZS', 'secondary_metric': 'sum__SP_POP_TOTL', 'country_controltype': 'cca2', 'max_bubble_size': '25', 'datasource': '2__table', 'time_grain_sqla': 'Time Column', 'viz_type': 'world_map', 'filters': [], 'having': '', 'show_bubbles': True}`

Am I missing something?

@kaiosama The hostname directs the sql-alchemy to use SQL at the given port. Hard to say whether a map reduce is the normal behavior to expect, without knowing details about your setup of hive, map reduce and spark.

i think it will be important to notify/confirm with a user that when a datasource is deleted, all related slices will be deleted as well. alternatively, could a slice be in a 'needs datasource` state, where it could still be accessed, or shown on a dashboard, but the chart wouldn't load and instead a message to the user would be displayed notifying them to update the datasource.
there is a workaround via specifying the metric to be MAX or MIN

Some more update on possible "Advanced tutorial". 
I found that the only explanation on "Series", "Entity", "Metric" etc was the live hint of "mouse-over". That would be cool if it could be explained somewhere connecting to the examples shipped. 
And it's also beneficial to add indicator of what's necessary and what's not. 
I was playing around with "Bubble" chart type with my own data. And I don't have Series/Entity recognized so it reports "Pick a metric for x,y and size" error which is very hard to understand since there is no "Metric" field at all.
Ok, I'll try to install from the `master`. Thanks!

I found this issue when I was searching for multiple tables support. In my application, I need to perform data analysis based on raw tables and then display it through superset (hopefully). My raw database used many small tables, while new table/view to be displayed could be stored in a materialized table for view purpose if needed. But I'm not sure if it's a proper use case for superset anymore. 
If anyone has comment, I'd like to see how this could be solved.

Add `df_timezone` function for all TimeSeries Slices:
```
NVD3TimeSeriesViz(NVD3Viz)
NVD3DualLineViz(NVD3Viz)
NVD3CompareTimeSeriesViz(NVD3TimeSeriesViz)
NVD3TimeSeriesBarViz(NVD3TimeSeriesViz)
NVD3TimeSeriesStackedViz(NVD3TimeSeriesViz)

```
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8108788/23699392/ed1b953c-0429-11e7-8b4e-4d830318ca80.png)
@mistercrunch could you tell me the exact commit that fixed the problem?

I think I have it:

https://github.com/airbnb/superset/commit/9d8d4213840cc07d95ac971437632aeae4ff58b5

This seems refers to a SQLAlchemy bug, which should be fixed in v1.2. It's patched for DateTimes in models.py :`Patch for sqlalchemy bug`
Bug ref: https://bitbucket.org/zzzeek/sqlalchemy/issues/3740/clean-up-doubling-of-percent-signs-base-on
in #2330 I started doubling the `%` in the WHERE clause and in the new LIKE clause of filters.
Exactly. Closing.
Using a view, materialized or not, is how you'd make that happen in Superset. It is a proper use case.
can we keep the formatting things outside this PR, codeclimate doesn't seem to agree with your auto-formatter.
@mistercrunch thanks for the update. Any visibility into the roadmap for future releases ?

Hello, 

I updated to 0.17.0

I'm still receiving 414 Request-URI Too Large, did this fix not make it in?

Bad Request
Request Line is too large (5491 > 4094)

I believe that this is related?

the same with me  with MS SQL DB .
preview works fine, but Run Query button rise error similar  to mentioned above: 

`/root/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/amqp/connection.py", line 186, in Transport return create_transport(host, connect_timeout, ssl) File "/root/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/amqp/transport.py", line 299, in create_transport return TCPTransport(host, connect_timeout) File "/root/venv/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/amqp/transport.py", line 95, in __init__ raise socket.error(last_err) error: [Errno 111] Connection refused`

it seems like a wrong configuration of Celery (Distributed task queue).  This part missed in documentation,  may be it needs in some configuration after installation?

Oh disregard my comment above, this has to do with `amqp`, which is Celery/RabbitMQ/Redis related. You can set the DB to only support synchronous query to test independently from Celery.

I also think @sungjuly were off target as the error message was misleading.
@vera-liu I'm merging this as I'm about to write tests for my related PR
Fun PR :) Great Job ! LGTM
LGTM

Thanks a lot @mistercrunch
I was wondering since I didn't fully get your comment above:
"A view is a simple logical layer that abstract an arbitrary SQL queries as a virtual table. This can allow you to join and union multiple tables, and to apply some transformation using arbitrary SQL expressions. "

Not sure I fully understand this. By "view" do you mean a class in views.py or just a SQL expression?
For me, I'll make some complicated data manipulating on raw tables so a simple SQL expression should not work. I'm not quite familiar with views.py(FAB) yet so I can't say too much about this.
I meant it in the database/SQL sense of the term, as in `CREATE VIEW foo AS SELECT...`

Appreciate it. Now I understand. 
My application will call python functions to do post-processing so I guess a materialized table(though it should be called data-source too) is necessary.
